editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: The gentleman vsher. By George Chapman.
Gentleman usher
Gentleman usher.
titleStmt.author: Chapman, George, 1559?-1634.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by V[alentine] S[immes] for Thomas Thorppe,

note.p: First word of title is xylographic.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.p: The gentleman usher. By George Chapman.
At London printed by v. s. for Thomas Thorpe. 1606.

sp.speaker: Strozza.
sp.p: Haste nephew, what, a sluggard? Fie for shame, shall he that was our morning cock, turn owl, and lock out day light from his drowsy eyes?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Pray pardon me for once, lord uncle, for I'll be sworn, I had such a dream this morning: methought one came with a commission to take a sorrel curtal, that was stolen from him, 〈◊〉 he could find him. And because I feared he would lay claim to my sorrel curtal in my stable I ran to the smith to have him set on his mane again, and his tail presently, that the commission-man might not think him a curtal. And when the smith would not do it, I fell a beating of him, so that I could not wake for my life till I was revenged on him.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: This is your old valour nephew, that will fight sleeping as well as waking.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: 'Slud aunt, what if my dream had been true ▪ (As it might have been for any thing I knew) there's never a smith in Italy, shall make an ass of me in my sleep, if I can choose.

lg.l: Well said, my furious nephew: but I see
You quite forget that we must rouse today
The sharp-tusked boar: and blaze our huntsmanship before the Duke.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p:
Forget lord uncle? I hope not; you think belike
my wits are as brittle as a beetle, or as skittish as your Barbary mare: one cannot cry weh●, but straight she cries tihi.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Well guessed cousin hysteron proteron.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: But which way will the Duke's grace hunt today?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Towards count Lasso's house his grace will hunt, where he will visit his late honoured mistress.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Who lady Mar●arot, that dear young dame? Will his antiquity, never lean his iniquity?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Why how now nephew? turned Parnassus lately?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nassus? I know not: but I would I had all the Dukes living for her sake, I'd make him a poor Duke i'faith.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: No doubt of that, if thou hadst all his living.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I would not stand dreaming of the matter as I do now.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Why how do you dream nephew?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Marry all last night methought I was tying her shoestring.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: What all night tying her shoestring?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I that I was, and yet I tied it not neither; for as I was tying it, the string broke methought , and then methought , having but one point at my hose, methought , I gave her that to tie her shoe with all.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: A point of much kindness I assure you.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Whereupon, in the y nick methought the count came rushing in, and I ran rushing out, with my heels about my hose for haste.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: So, will you leave your dreaming, and dispatch?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Mum, not a word more, I'll go before, and overtake you presently.

lg.l: My lord I fancy not these hunting sports,
When the bold game you follow turns again,
And stares you in the face: let me behold
A cast of falcons on their merry wings,
Daring the stooped prey, that shifting flies:
Or let me view the fearful hare or hind,
To●t like a music point with harmony
Of well mouthed hounds. This is a sport for princes,
The other rude boars yield fit game for boors.
Thy timorous spirit blinds thy judgement, wife,
Those are most royal sports that most approve
the huntsman's prowess, and his hardy mind.
My lord, I know too well your virtuous spirit,
Take heed for god's love if you rouse the boar,
You come not near him, but discharge aloof
Your wounding pistol, or well aimed dart.
I marry wife this counsel rightly flows
Out of thy bosom, pray thee take less care,
Let ladies at their tables judge of boars,
Lords in the field: and so farewell sweet love;
Fail not to meet me at Earl Lasso's house.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Pray pardon me for that: you know I love not these solemn meetings.

lg.l: You must needs, for once
Constrain your disposition; and indeed
I would acquaint you more with lady Margaret,
For special reason.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Very good, my lord. Then I must needs go fit me for that presence.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I pray thee do, farewell.
Here comes my friend.

lg.l: Good day my lord; why does your grace confront
So clear a morning with so cloudy looks?
Askest thou my griefs, that knowest my desperate love
Curbed by my father's stern reality:
Must not I mourn that know not whether yet
I shall enjoy a stepdame or a wife?
A wife prince, never doubt it; your deserts
And youthful graces have engaged so far,
The beauteous Margaret, that she is your own.
O but the eye of watchful jealousy
Robs my desires of meanest enjoy her favour.
Despair not: there are means enough for you,
Suborn some servant of some good respect,
That's near your choice, who though she needs no wooing,
May yet imagine you are to begin,
Your strange young love suit, and so speak for you,
Bear your kind letters, and get safe access.
All which when he shall do; you need not fear
His trusty secrecy, because he dares not
reveal escapes, where of himself is author,
Whom you may best attempt, she must reveal;
For if she loves you, she already knows,
And in an instant can resolve you that.
And so she will, I doubt not: would to heaven
I had fit time, even now to know her mind:
This counsel feeds my heart with much sweet hope.
Pursue it then; 'twill not be hard t'effect:
The Duke has none for him, but Medice
That fustian lord, who in his buckram face,
Bewrays, in my conceit, a map of baseness.
Ay, there's a parcel of unconstrued stuff,
That unknown minion raised to honour's height,
Without the help of virtue, or of art,
Or (To say true) nay of honest part:
Oh how she shames my father! he goes like
A prince's footman, in old fashioned silks,
And most times, in his hose and doublet only,
So miserable, that his own few men
Do beg by virtue of his livery;
For he gives none for any service done him,
Or any honour, any least reward.
'Tis pity such should live about a prince:
I would have such a noble counterfeited, nailed
Upon the pillory, and after, whipped
For his adultery with nobility,
Faith I would fain disgrace him by all means,
As enemy to his base-bred ignorance,
That being a great lord, cannot write nor read.
For that, we'll follow the blind side of him,
And make it sometimes subject of our mirth.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: See, what news with your nephew Pogio?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: None good I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Where should I find my lord uncle?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: What's the huge haste with you?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: O ho, you will hunt today.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I hope I will.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: But you may hap to hop without your hope: for the truth is, Kilbucke is run mad.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis true sir: and Ki●bucke being run mad, bit Ringwood so by the left buttock, you might have turned your nose in it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Out ass.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: By heaven you might my lord: d'ye think I he?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: 'Zounds, might I? let's blanket him my lord: a blanket here.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nay, good my lord Vincentio, by this rush I tell you for good will: and Venus your brach there, runs so proud, that your hunt's man cannot take her down for his life.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Take her up fool, thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Why sir, he would soon take her down and he could take her up I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: Well said, ham mer, hammer.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Nay, good now let's alone, and there's your horse, grey Strozza too has the staggers, and has struck bay. Bettrice, your Barbary mare so, that she goes halting a this fashion, most filthily.

sp.speaker: Stro.

lg.l: What poison blisters thy unhappy tongue
Evermore braying forth unhappy news,
Our hunting sport is at the best my lord:
How shall I satisfy the Duke your father,
Defrauding him of his expected sport?
See, see, he comes.

sp.stage: Enter Alphonso, Medice, Sarpego, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Is this the copy of the speech you wrote, signieur Sarpego?

lg.l: It is a blaze of wit poetical,
Read it, brave Duke, with eyes pathetical.
We will peruse it straight: well met Vincentio,
And good lord Strozza, we commend you both
For your attendance: but you must conceive,
'Tis no true hunting we intend today,
But an inducement to a certain show,
Wherewith we will present our beauteous love,
And therein we bespeak your company.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: We both are ready to attend your highness.

lg.l: See then, here is a poem that requires
Your worthy censures; offered if it like
To furnish our intended amorous show:
Read it Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Pardon me my lord, lord Medici's reading, will express it better ▪

lg.l: My patience can digest your scoffs my lord.
I care not to proclaim it to the world:
I can nor write, nor read; and what of that?
I can both see and hear, as well as you.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Still are your wits at war: here, read this poem.

lg.l: The red faced sun hath firked the flundering shades,
And cast bright ammell on Aurora's brow.
High words and strange:
Read on Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: The busky groves that gag-toothed boars do shroud with cringle-crange horns do ring aloud.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: My lord, my lord, I have a speech here worth ten of this, and yet I'll mend it too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: How likes Vincentio?

lg.l: It is strangely good,
No inkhorn ever did bring forth the like,
Could these brave prancing words with actions spur,
Be ridden thoroughly, and managed right,
'Twould fright the audience, and perhaps delight.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.p: Doubt you of action sir?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ay, for such stuff.

lg.l: Then know my lord, I can both act and teach
To any words; when I in Padua schooled it,
I played in one of Plautus comedies,
Namely, Curc●o, where his part I acted,
Projecting from the poor sum of four lines,
Forty fair actions.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Let's see that I pray.

lg.l: Your highness shall command,
But pardon me, if in my action's heat
Entering in post post haste I chance to take up
some of your honoured heels;

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Y'ad best leave out that action for a thing that I know sir.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.p: Then shall you see what I can do without it.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: See see, he hath his furniture and all.

lg.l: You must imagine, lords, I bring good news,
Whereof being princely proud I scour the street
And over-tumble every man I meet.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Beshrew my heart if he take up my heels.

lg.l: Date viam mihi noti, atque ignoti.
Dum ego, hîc, officium meum facio.
Fugite omnes atque abite, et de via secedite, ne quem
In cursu; aut capite, aut cubito, aut pectore offendam, aut genu.
Thanks good Seigneur Sarpego.
How like you lords, this stirring action?
In a cold morning it were good my lord.
But something harsh upon repletion.
Sir I have ventured, being enjoined to eat
Three scholars commons, and yet drew it neat.

sp.speaker: Pogio.
sp.p: Come sir, you meddle in too many matters; let us ● prey tend on our own show at my lord lassos.

lg.l: Doing obeisance then to every lord
I now consort you sir even toto cord.
My lord, away with these scholastic wits,
Lay the invention of your speech on me,
And the performance too; I'll play my part,
That you shall say, nature yields more than art.
Be't so resolved; unartificial truth
An unfeigned passion can decipher best.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But 'twill be hard my lord, for one unlearned.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Unlearned? I cry you mercy sir; unlearned?

lg.l: I mean, untaught my lord, to make a speech,
As a pretended actor, without close,
More gracious than your doublet and your hose.
What, think you son we mean t'express a speech
Of special weight without a like attire?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Excuse me then my lord; so stands it well.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Has brought them rarely in, to pageant him.

lg.l: What; think you lord; we think not of attire?
Can we not make us ready at this age?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Alas my lord, your wit must pardon his.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I hope it will, his wit is pitiful.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I pray stand by my lord; you're troublesome.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: To none but you; am I to you my lord?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Not unto me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Why then you wrong me Strozza.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Nay, fall not out my lords.

lg.l: May I not know
What your speech is my liege?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: None but myself, and the lord Medice.

lg.l: No, pray my lord
Let none partake with us.
No be assured,
But for another cause; a word lord Strozza,
I tell you true, I fear lord Medice
Will scarce discharge the speech effectually:
As we go therefore, I'll explain to you
My whole intent; that you may second him
If need and his debility require.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Thanks for this grace my liege.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: My lord; your son.

lg.l: Why how now son? forbear; yet 'tis no matter
We talk of other business Medice
And come, we will prepare us to our show.

sp.speaker: Stro. Vin.
sp.p: Which as we can, we'll cast to overthrow.
sp.stage: Enter Lasso, Corteza, Margaret, Bassiolo, Sarpego, two pages, Bassiolo bore before.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Stand by there, make place.

lg.l: Say now Bassiolo; you on whom relies
The general disposition of my house,
In this our preparation, for the Duke
Are all our officers at large instructed,
For fit discharge of their peculiar places?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: At large my lord instructed.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Are all our chambers hung? Think you our house amply capacious to lodge all the train?

lg.l: Amply capacious: I am passing glad.
And now then to our mirth and musical show,
Which after supper we intend t'indure,
Welcomes chief dainties: for choice cates at home,
Ever attend on princes; mirth abroad,
Are all parts perfect.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.p: One I know there is.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: And that is yours.

lg.l: Well guest in earnest lord,
I need not erubescere , to take
So much upon me: that my back will bear.
Nay, he will be perfection itself,
For wording well, and dexterous action too.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: And will these waggish pages, hit their songs?

sp.speaker: 2 Pag.
sp.p: Remi fa solla?

lg.l: O they are practising; good boys, well done;
But where is Pogio? there you're overshot.
To lay a capital part upon his brain,
Whose absence tells me plainly he'll neglect him.
O no my lord, he dreams of nothing else,
And gives it out in wagers, he'll excel;
And see, (I told your lo:) he is come.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: How now my lord, have you borrowed a snite for me: seigneur Bassiolo, can all say, are all things ready? the Duke is hard by, and little thinks that I'll be an actor i'faith, I keep all close my lord.

lg.l: O, 'tis well done, call all the ladies in,
Sister and daughter, come, for god's sake come,
Prepare your courtliest carriage for the Duke.
Corte and niece, in any case remember this,
Praise the old man, and when you see him first,
Look me on none but him, smiling and lovingly:
And then, when he comes near, make 'beisance low,
With both your hands thus moving, which not only
Is as 'twere courtly, and most comely too,
But speaks (As who should say) come hither Duke;
And yet says nothing, but you may deny.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Well taught sister.

lg.l: Ay, and to much end:
I am exceeding fond to humour him.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Hark, does he come with music? what, and bound?
An amorous device: daughter, observe.
sp.stage: Enter enchanter, with spirits singing; after them; Medice, like S●anus, next the Duke bound, Vincentio, Strozza, with other.

lg.l: Now let's gull Medi●, I do not doubt,
But this attire put on, will put him out.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: We'll do our best to that end, therefore mark.

lg.l: Lady, or Princess, both your choice commands.
These spirits and I, all servants of your beauty,
Present this royal captive to your mercy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Captive to me a subject.

lg.l: Ay, fair nymph;
And how the worthy mystery befell
Sylvanvs here, this wooden god can tell.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Now my lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: No● the time man, speak.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Peace Vincentio.

lg.l: 'Swounds my lord,
Shall I stand by and suffer him to shame you?
My lord Medice?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Will you not speak my lord?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: How can I?

lg.l: But you must speak in earnest:
Would not your highness h● him speak my lord?
Yes, and I will speak, and perhaps speak so,
As you shall never mend: I can I know.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Do then my good lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Medice, forth.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Goddess, fair goddess, for no less, no less.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No. Less, no less ▪ no more, no more: speak you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: 'Swounds they have put me out.

lg.l: Laugh your fair goddess,
This nobleman disdains to be your fool.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Vincentio, peace.

lg.l: 'Swounds my lord, i● is as good a show:
Pray speak lord Strozza.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.p: Honourable dame.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Take heed you be not out I pray my lord.

lg.l: I pray forbear my lord Vincentio:
How this distressed prince came thus enthralled,
I must relate with words of height and wonder:
His grace this morning visiting the woods,
And straying far, to find game for the chase,
At last, out of a myrtle grove he roused
A vast and dreadful boar, so stern and fierce ▪
As if the fiend fell cruelty herself
Had come to fright the woods in that strange shape.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Excellent good.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Too good a plague on him.

lg.l: The princely savage being thus on foot,
Tearing the earth up with his thundering hoof,
And with th'enraged Aetna of his breath.
Firing the air, and scorching all the woods,
Horror held all us huntsmen from pursuit,
Only the Duke incensed with our cold fear,
Encouraged like a second Hercules.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Zounds, too good man.

lg.l: Pray thee let me alone:
And like the English sign of great saint George.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Plague of that simile.

lg.l: Gave valorous example, and like fire,
Hunted the monster close, and charged so fierce,
That he enforced him (As our sense conceived)
To leap for soil into a crystal spring,
Where on the sudden strangely vanishing,
Nymph-like for him, out of the waves arose
Your sacred figure like Diana armed,
And (As in purpose of the beast's revenge)
Discharged an arrow through his highness' breast ▪
Whence yet no wound or any blood appeared ▪
With which, the angry shadow left the light:
And this enchanter with his power of spirits,
Broke from a cave, scattering enchanted sounds,
That struck us senseless, while in these strange bands,
These cruel spirits thus inchained his arms,
and led him captive to your heavenly eyes ▪
Th'intent whereof on their report relies.
Bright nymph, that boar figured your cruelty,
Chared by love, defended by your beauty.
This amorous huntsman here, we thus enthralled,
As the attendants on your grace's charms,
And brought him hither by your bounteous hands.
To be released, or live in endless bands.
Daughter, release the Duke: alas my liege.
What meant your highness to endure this wrong?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Enlarge him niece, come dame, it must be so ▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What madam, shall I arrogate so much?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: His highness' pleasure is to grace you so.

lg.l: Perform it then sweet love, it is a deed
Worthy the office of your honoured hand.
Too worthy I confess my lord for me,
If it were serious: but it is in sport,
And women are fit actors for such pageants.
Thanks gracious love; why made you strange of this?
I rest no less your captive then before,
For me untying, you have tied me more.
Thanks Strozza for your speech, no thanks to you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: No, thank your son my lord.

lg.l: Was very well,
Exceeding well performed on every part,
How say you Bassiolo?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Rare I protest my lord.

lg.l: O, my lord Medice became it rarely,
Methought I liked his manly being out;
It becomes noblemen to do nothing well.
Now then wil't please your grace to grace our house,
And still vouchsafe our service further honour.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Lead us my lord, we will your daughter lead.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You do not lead, but drag her leaden steps.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: How did you like my speech?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O fie upon't, your rhetoric was too fine.

lg.l: Nothing at all:
I hope saint George's sign was gross enough:
but (To be serious) as these warnings pass,
Watch you your father, I'll watch Medice,
That in your love-suit, we may shun suspect:
To which end, with your next occasion, urge
Your love to name the person she will choose,
By whose means you may safely write or meet.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: That's our chief business: and see, here she comes.

lg.l: My lord, I only come to say, you're welcome ▪
And so must say, farewell.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: One word I pray.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's that?

lg.l: You needs must presently devise,
What person trusted chiefly with your guard,
You think is aptest for me to corrupt,
In making him a mean for our safe meeting?
My father's usher, none so fit,
If you can work him well: and so farewell,
With thanks my good lord Strozza for your speech.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I thank you for your patience, mocking lady.

lg.l: O what a fellow has she picked us out?
One that I would have choosed passed all the rest,
For his close stockings only.
And why not?
For the most constant fashion of his hat?
Nay then, if nothing must be left unspoke,
For his strict form, thus still to wear his cloak.
Well sir, he is your own, I make no doubt:
For to these outward figures of his mind,
He hath two inward swallowing properties
Of any gudgeons; servile avarice,
And overweening thought of his own worth,
Ready to snatch at every shade of glory:
And therefore, till you can directly board him,
Waft him aloof with hats, and other favours,
Still as you meet him.
Well, let me alone,
He that is one man's slave, is free from no●.

div.head: Actus secundus
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Medice, Corteza a page with a cup of secke, Strozza following close.

lg.l: Come lady, sit you here: page, fill some sack,
I am to work upon this aged dame,
To glean from her, if there be any cause
(In loving others) of her niece's coins
To the most gracious love suit of the Duke:
Here noble lady, this is healthful drink
After our supper.
O, 'tis that my lord,
That of all drinks keeps life and soul in me.
Here, fill it page, for this my worthy love ▪
Oh how I could embrace this good old widow.
Now lord, when you do thus, you make me think
Of my sweet husband; for he was as like you;
E'en the same words, and fashion: the same eyes,
Manly, and choleric, e'en as you are just,
And e'en as kind as you for all the world.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: O my sweet widow, thou dost make me proud.

sp.speaker: Cort:
sp.p: Nay, I am too old for you.

lg.l: Too old, that's nothing,
Come pledge me wench, for I am dry again,
And straight will charge your widowhood fresh i'faith:
Why that's well done.

sp.speaker: Cort:
sp.p: Now fie on't, here's a draught.

lg.l: O, it will warm your blood: if you should sip,
'Twould make you heart burned.
Faith and so they say:
Yet I must tell you, since I plied this gear,
I have been haunted with a whoreson pain here,
And every moon almost with a shrewd fever,
And yet I cannot leave it: for thank God,
I never was more sound of wind and limb.
Look you, I warrant you I have a leg,
holds out as handsomely.
Beshrew my life,
But 'tis a leg indeed, a goodly limb.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: This is most excellent.

lg.l: O that your niece
Were of as mild a spirit as yourself.
Alas lord Medice, would you have a girl.
As well seen in behaviour as I?
Ah she's a fond young thing, and grown so proud ▪
The wind must blow at West still, or she'll be angry.
Mass so methink ; how coy she's to the Duke?
I lay my life she has some younger love.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: Faith like enough.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: God's me, who should it be?

lg.l: If it be any; page, a little sack.
If it be any: hark now; if it be,
I know not, by this sack, but if it be,
Mark what I say, my lord; I drink tee first.
Well said good widow, much good do thy heart ▪
So; now what if it be?
Well, if it be;
To come to that I said, for so I said,
If it be any, 'tis the shrewd young prince,
For eyes can speak, and eyes can understand ▪
And I have marked her eyes; yet by this cup,
Which I will only kiss.
O noble crone,
Now such a huddle and kettle never was.
I never yet have seen; not yet I say,
But I will mark her after for your sake.
And do I pray; for it is passing like;
And there is Strozza, a sly counsellor
To the young boy: oh I would give a limb,
To have their knavery limned and painted out.
They stand upon their wits and paper learning:
Give me a fellow with a natural wit,
That can make wit of no wit; and wade through
Great things with nothing, when their wits stick fast,
Oh they be scurvy lords.
Faith so they be,
Your lordship still is of my mind in all,
And ●ene so was my husband.
God's my life,
Strozza ▪ hath eavesdropped here, and overheard us.
They have descried me; what lord Medice
Courting the lusty widow?
Ay, and why not?
Perhaps one does as much for you at home.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: What, choleric man? and towards wedlock too?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: And if he be my lord; he may do worse.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: If he be not; madam he may do better.
sp.stage: Enter Bassiolo with servants with rushes, and a carpet.

lg.l: My lords, and madam, the Duke's grace entreats you
T'attend his new-made Duchess for this night,
Into his presence.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: We are ready sir.

lg.l: Come strew this room afresh; spread here this carpet,
Nay quickly man, I pray thee; this way fool,
Lay me it smooth, and even; look if he will;
This way a little more: a little there.
Hast thou no forecast? ●lood methinks a man
Should not of mere necessity be an ass.
Look how he strews here too: come sir Giles Goosecap,
I must do all myself, lay me 'em thus:
In fine smooth threaves, look you sir, thus in threaves.
Perhaps some tender lady will squat here,
And if some standing rush should chance to prick her,
She'd squeak and spoil the songs that must be sung.
See where he is; now to him, and prepare
Your familiarity.
Save you master Bassiolo,
I pray a word sir; but I fear I let you.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: No my good lord, no let.

lg.l: I thank you sir.
Nay pray be covered; oh I cry you mercy,
You must be bare.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Ever to you my lord,

lg.l: Nay, not to me sir,
but to the fair right of your worshipful place.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: A shame of both your worships.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: What means your lordship?

lg.l: Only to do you right sir, and myself ease.
And what sir, will there be some show tonight ?
A slender presentation of some music
And some thing else my lord.
'Tis passing good sir,
I'll not be over bold t'ask the particulars.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Yes, if your lordship please.

lg.l: O no good sir,
But I did wonder much; for as methought
I saw your hands at work.
Or else my lord
Our business would be but badly done.
How virtuous is a worthy man's example?
Who is this throne for prey?
For my lord's daughter,
Whom the Duke makes to represent his Duchess.
'Twill be exceeding fit; and all this room
Is passing well prepared; a man would swear,
That all presentments in it would be rare.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, see if thou canst lay 'em thus in threaves.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: In threaves d'ye call it?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I my lord in threaves.

lg.l: A pretty term:
Well sir I thank you highly for this kindness,
And pray you always make as bold with me
For kindness more than this, if more may be.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O my lord this is nothing.

lg.l: Sir, 'tis much.
And now I'll leave you sir; I know you're busy.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Faith sir a little.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I commend me ●ee sir.

lg.l: A courteous prince believe it; I am sorry
I was no bolder with him; what a phrase
He used at parting ▪ I commend me tee ▪
Be h●ate i'faith;
Good master usher, will you dictate to me,
Which is the part precedent of this nightcap,
And which posterior? I do ignorare
How I should wear it.
Why sir; this I take it
Is the precedent part; ay, so it is.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.p: And is all well sir think you?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Passing well.

lg.l: Why sir come on; the usher shall be judge:
See master usher: this same Fungus here,
Your lords retainer, whom I hope you rule,
Would wear this better jerkin for the rushman,
When I do play the broom-man; and speak first.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Why sir, I borrowed it, and I will wear it.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: What sir, in spite of your lords gentleman, usher:

lg.l: No spite sir, but you have changed twice already,
And now would have't again.
Why that's all one sir,
Gentility must be fantastical.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I pray thee Fungus let master Pogio wear it.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: And what shall I wear then?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Why here is one, that was a rush-man's jerkin, and I pray, were't not absurd then; a broom-man should wear it?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Foe, there's a reason, I will keep it sir.

lg.l: Will sir; then do your office master usher,
Make him put off his jerkin; you may pluck
His coat over his cares, much more his jerkin.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Fungus y'ad best be ruled.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Best sir! I care not.

lg.l: No sir? I hope you are my lords retainer.
I need not care a pudding for your lord:
But spare not, keep it, for perhaps I'll play
My part as well in this, as you in that,

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well said, master Pogio; my lord shall know it.
sp.stage: Enter Corteza, with the broom-wench, and rush-wench in their petticoats, cloaks over them, with hats over their head-tires.

lg.l: Look master usher, are these wags well dressed?
I have been so in labour with 'em truly.

sp.speaker: Bass.

lg.l: You've had a very good deliverance, lady:
How I did take her at her labour there,
I use to gird these ladies so sometimes.

sp.stage: Enter Lasso, with Syl● and a nymph, a man bug, and a woman.
sp.p: 1 I pray my lord, must not I wear this hair?

lg.l: I pray thee ask my usher; come, dispatch,
The Duke is ready: are you ready there?
2 see master usher; must he wear this hair?
Pray master usher, where must I come in?
2 am not I well for a bug, master usher?
What stir is with these boys here, God forgive me,
If 'twere not for the credit on't, I'd see
Your apish trash attire, ere I'd endure this.
1 but pray good master usher.
Hence ye brats,
You stand upon your tire; but for your action
Which you must use in singing of your songs,
Exceeding dexterously and full of life,
I hope you'll then stand like a sort of blocks,
Without due motion of your hands, and heads,
And wresting your whole bodies to your words,
Look to't, you're best; and in; go; all go in:

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Come in my masters; let's be out anon.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: What, are all furnish well?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: All well my lord.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: More lights than here, and let loud music sound.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Sound music.
sp.stage: Enter Vincentio, Stro●bare, Margaret, Corteza, and Cynanche bearing her train. After her the Duke whispering with Medice, Lasso with bassiolo, etc.

lg.l: Advance yourself, fair Duchess to this throne ▪
As we have long since raised you to our heart,
Better decorum never was beheld,
Then twixt this state and you: and as all eyes
Now fixed on your bright graces think it fit,
So frame your favour to continue it.
My lord; but to obey your earnest will,
And not make serious scruple of a joy,
I scarce durst have pres●de this minute height.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Usher, cause other music; begin your show.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Sound consort; warn the pedant to be ready.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam, I think you'll see a pretty show.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I can expect no less in such a presence.

lg.l: Lo what attention and state beauty breeds,
Whose moaning silence no shrill herald needs.
Lords of high degree,
And ladies of low courtesy,
I the pedant here,
Whom some call schoolmaster,
Because I can speak best,
Approach before the rest.

sp.speaker: Vi●.
sp.p: A very good reason.

lg.l: But there are others coming,
Without mask or mumming:
For they are not ashamed,
If need be, to be named,
Nor will they hide their faces,
In any place or places;
For though they seem to come,
Loaded with rush, and broom:
The broomeman you must know,
Is seigneur Pogio,
Nephew, as shall appear,
To my lord Strozza here.
O lord, I thank you sir, you grace me much.
And to this noble dame,
Whom I with finger name.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: A plague of that fool's finger.

sp.speaker: Sar.

lg.l: And women will ensue,
Which I must tell you true,
No women are indeed,
But pages made for need,
To fill up women's places.
By virtue of their faces,
And other hidden graces.
A hall, a hall; whist, still, be mum,
For now with silver song they come.

sp.stage: Enter Pogio, Fungus, with the song broom-maid, and rush-maid. After which, Pogio.

lg.l: Heroes, and heroines, of gallant strain,
Let not these brooms, motes in your eyes remain,
For in the moon, there's one bears withered bushes:
But we (Dear wights) do bear green brooms, green rushes,
Where of these verdant herbals cleped broom,
Do pierce and enter every lady's room,
And to prove them high born, and no base trash,
Water with which your phisnomies you wash,
Is but a broom. And more truth to deliver,
Grim Hercules swept a stable with a river,
The wind that sweeps foul clouds out of the air,
And for you ladies makes the welkin fair,
Is but a broom: and oh dan Titan bright,
Most clearkly called the scavenger of night,
What art thou, but a very broom of gold?
For all this world not to be cried nor sold;
Philosophy, that passion sweeps from thought,
Is the soul's broom, and by all brave wits sought,
Now if philosophers but broom-men are,
Each broomeman then is a philosopher.
And so we come (Gracing your gracious graces)
To sweep cares cobwebs from your cleanly faces.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Thanks good master broomeman,

lg.l: For me Rushman then,
To make rush ruffle in a u●pse of ten,
A rush which now your heels do lie on here.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Cry mercy sir.

lg.l: Was whilom used for a pungent spear,
In that odd battle, never fought but twice
(As homer●ings) betwixt the frogs and mice,
rushes make true-love know; rushes make rings,
Your rush maugre the beard of whiter springs:
And when with gentle, amorous, ●ay lazy limbs,
Each lord with his fair lady sweetly swims
On these cool rushes; they may with these babbles,
Cradles for children make; children for cradles,
And lest some Momus here might now ●rie push,
Saying our pageant is not worth a rush,
Bundles of rushes, lo, we bring along,
To pick his teeth that bites them with his tongue.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: See, see, that's lord M●dice.

lg.l: God's me, my lord,
Has he picked you out, pi●ing of your t●h?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: What pick you out of that?

lg.l: Not such qq stu●
As you pick from your teeth.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Leave this war with rushes,
Good master pedant; pray forth with your show.

lg.l: Lo thus far then (Brave Duke) you see
Mere entertainment; now our gl●
Shall march forth in 〈◊〉:
And this quaint Duchess here shall see
The fault of virgin nicety,
First wooed with rural courtesy,
Disburden them; prance on this ground,
And make your exit with your round.
Well have they danced as it is meet,
Both with their nimble heads and feet.
Now, as our country girls held off,
And rudely did their lover's scoff;
Our nymph likewise shall only glance
By your fair eyes, and look askance
Upon her female friend that wo●es her.
Who is in plain field forced to lose her.
And after them, to conclude all,
The p●rlue of our pastoral.
A female bug, and eke her friend,
Shall only come and sing, and end
This lady and Duchess we conclude,
Fair virgins must not be too rude:
For though the rural wild and ●ntike,
Abused their loves as they were franuke;
Yet take you in your ivory clutches,
This noble Duke, and be his Duchesses.
Thus thanking all for their tacete,
I vo● the room, and cry valete.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Generally well, and pleasingly performed.

lg.l: Now I resign this borrowed majesty,
Which sat unseemly on my worthless head,
With humble service to your highness' hands.
Well you became it lady, and I know
All here could wish it might be ever so.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Here's one says nay to that.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Plague on you, peace.

lg.l: Now let it please your highness to accept
A homely banquet, to close these rude sports.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I thank your lordship much.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Bring lights, make place.
sp.stage: Enter Pogi● in his cloak and broom-mans attire.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: How d'ye my lord?

sp.speaker: Alp
sp.p: O master broomeman, you did passing well.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: A you mad slave you! you are a tickling actor.

lg.l: I was not out like my lord Medice.
How did you like me aunt?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O rarely, rarely.

lg.l: O thou hast done a work of memory,
And raised our house up higher by a story.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Friend, how conceit you my young mother here?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Fitter for you my lord, than for your father.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: No more of that sweet friend, those are bugs words.

div.head: Actus tertii
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Medice after the song, whispers alone with his servant.

lg.l: Thou art my trusty servant and thou know'st,
I have been ever bountiful lord to thee,
As still I will be: be thou thankful then,
And do me now a service of import.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Any my lord in compass of my life.

lg.l: Tomorrow then the Duke intends to hunt,
Where Strozza my despiteful enemy,
Will give attendance busy in the chase,
Wherein (As if by chance, when others shoot
At the wild boar) do thou discharge at him,
And with an arrow, cleave his cankered heart.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I will not fail my lord.

lg.l: Be secret then.
And thou to me shalt be the dearest of men.
Now vanity and policy enrich me
With some ridiculous fortune on this usher.
Where's master usher?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Now I come my lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Besides, good sir, your show did show so well,

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Did it in deed my lord?

lg.l: O sir, believe it;
'Twas the best fashioned and well ordered thing
That ever eye beheld: and there withal,
The fit attendance by the servants used,
The gentle guise in serving every guest,
In other entertainments; every thing
About your house so sortfully disposed,
That even as in a turnspit called a Jack,
One vice assists another; the great wheels
Turning but softly, make the less to whirr
About their business; every different part
Concurring to one commendable end:
So, and in such conformance, with rare grace,
Were all things ordered in your good lord's house.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: The most fit simile that ever was.

lg.l: But shall I tell you plainly my conceit,
Touching the man that I think caused this order?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I good my lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You note my simile.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Drawn from the turnspit.

lg.l: I see you have me,
Even as in that quaint engine you have seen,
A little man in shreds stand at the window,
and seems to put all things in act about him,
Lifting and pulling with a mighty stir,
Yet adds no force to it, nor nothing does:
So, (Though your lord be a brave gentleman)
And seems to do this business,
He does nothing;
Some man about him was the festival robe,
That made him show so glorious and divine.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I cannot tell my lord, yet I should know if any such there were.

lg.l: Should know quoth you;
I warrant you know: well, some there be
Shall have the fortune to have such rare men,
(Like brave beasts to their arms) support their state,
When others of as high a worth and breed,
Are made the wasteful food of them they feed:
What state hath your lord made you for your service?
He has been my good lord, for I can spend
Some fifteen hundred crowns in lands a year,
Which I have gotten since I served him first.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: No more than fifteen hundred crowns a year?

lg.l: It is so much as makes me like my lord,
Like a poor gentleman.
Nay, 'tis pretty well:
But certainly my nature does esteem
Nothing enough for virtue; and had I
The Duke my father's means, all should be spent,
To keep brave men about me: but good sir,
Accept this simple jewel at my hands,
Till I can work persuasion of my friendship,
With worthier arguments.
No good my lord,
I can by no means merit the free bounties
You have bestowed besides.
Nay, be not strange,
But do yourself right, and be all one man
In all your actions, do not think but some
Have extraordinary spirits like yourself,
And will not stand in their society,
on birth and riches: but on worth and virtue,
With whom there is no niceness, nor respect
Of others common friendship; be he poor
Or basely born, so he be rich in soul,
And noble in degrees of qualities,
He shall be my friend sooner than a King.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: To a most kingly judgement in your lordship,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Faith sir I know not, but 'tis my vain humour.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O, 'tis an honour in a nobleman.

lg.l: You've some lords now so politic and proud,
They scorn to give good looks to worthy men.
O fie upon 'em; by that light my lord,
I am but servant to a nobleman,
But if I would not scorn such puppet lords,
Would I wear breathless.
You sir? so you may,
For they will cog so when they wish to use men,
With, pray be covered sir, I beseech you sit,
Who's there? wait of master usher to the door.
O, these be godly gudgeons: where's the deeds?
The perfect nobleman?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O good my lord.

lg.l: Away, away, ere I would flatter so,
I would eat rushes like lord Medici.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well, well my lord, would there were more such princes.

lg.l: Alas, 'twere pity sir, they would be gulled
Out of their very skins.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why how are you my lord?

lg.l: Who I, I care not:
If I beguiled where I profess plain love,
'Twill be their faults you know.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O 'twere their shames.

lg.l: Well, take my jewel, you shall not be strange,
I love not many words.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: My lord, I thank you, I am of few words too.

lg.l: Ti●●riendlie said,
You prove yourself a friend, and I would have you
Advance your thoughts, and lay about for state,
worthy your virtues: be the minion
Of some great King or Duke: there's Medici,
The minion of my father: oh the father!
What difference is there? but I cannot flatter
A word to wise men.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I perceive your lordship.

lg.l: Your lordship? talk you now like a friend?
Is this plain kindness?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Is it not my lord?

lg.l: A palpable flattering figure for men common:
A my word I should think, if 'twere another,
He meant to gull me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why 'tis but your due.

lg.l: 'Tis but my due: if you'll be still a stranger:
But as I wish to choose you for my friend,
As I intend when God shall call my father,
To do I can tell what: but let that pass,
Thus 'tis not fit; let my friend be familiar,
V●e not me lordship, nor yet call me lord,
Nor my whole name Vincentio; but Vince,
As they call Jack or will, 'tis now in use,
Twixt men of no equality or kindness.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I shall be quickly bold enough my lord.

lg.l: Nay, see how still you use that coy term, lord
What argues this, but that you shun my friendship?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay ▪ pray say not so.

lg.l: Who should not say so?
Will you afford me now no name at all?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: What should I call you?

lg.l: Nay, then 'tis no matter.
But I told you Vince.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why then my sweet Vince.

lg.l: Wh●e so then; and yet ●ull there is a fault,
In using these kind words, without kind deeds:
Pray thee embrace me too.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why then sweet Vince.

lg.l: Why now I thank you, 'sblood shall friends be strange?
Where there is plainness, there is ever truth:
And I will still be plain since I am true:
Come let us lie a little, I am weary.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: And so am I, I swear since yesterday.

lg.l: You may sir by my faith; and sirrah, hark thee,
What lordship wouldst thou wish to have i'faith,
When my old father dies?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Who I? alas.

lg.l: O not you, well sir, you shall have none,
You are as coy a piece as your lords daughter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Who, my mistress?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Indeed, is she your mistress?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: i'faith sweet Vince, since she was three year old.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And are not we too friends?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Who doubts of that?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And are not two friends one?

sp.speaker: Basis.
sp.p: Even man and wife.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Then what to you she is, to me she should be.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why Vince, thou wouldst not have her?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O not I: I do not fancy any thing like you ▪

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay but I pray thee tell me.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.p: You do not mean to marry her yourself?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Not I by heaven.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Take heed now, do not gull me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: No by that candle.

lg.l: Then will I be plain.
Think you she dotes not too much on my father?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O yes, no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Nay, I pray you speak.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: You silly man you, she cannot abide him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Why sweet friend pardon me, alas I knew not.

lg.l: But I do note you are in some things simple,
And wrong yourself too much.
Thank you good friend,
For your plain dealing, I do mean so well.
But who saw ever summer mixed with winter?
There must be equal years where firm love is.
Could we two love so well so suddenly
Were we not some thing equaller in years.
Than he and she are?
I cry ye mercy sir, I know we could not, but yet be not too bitter,
considering love is fearful. And sweet friend,
I have a letter t'entreat her kindness.
Which if you would convey.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Ay, if I would sir?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Why faith, dear friend, I would not die requiteless.

lg.l: Would you not so sir?
By heaven a little thing would make me box you,
Which if you would convey? why not I pray?
Which (Friend) thou shalt convey.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Which friend, you shall then.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well friend, and I will then.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And use some kind persuasive words for me?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: The best I swear that my poor tongue can forge.

lg.l: Ay, well said, poor tongue: oh 'tis rich in meekness;
You are not known to speak well? You have won
Direction of the Earl and all his house,
The favour of his daughter, and all dames
That ever I saw, come within your sight,
With a poor tongue? A plague a your sweet lips.
Well, we will do our best: and faith my Vince,
She shall have an unwieldy and dull soul,
If she be nothing moved with my poor tongue,
Call it no better; be it what it will.
Well said i'faith; now if I do not think
'Tis possible, besides her bare receipt
Of that my letter, with thy friendly tongue.
To get an answer of it, never trust me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: An answer man? 'sblood make no doubt of that.

lg.l: By heaven I think so; now a plague of nature,
That she gives all to some, and none to others.
How I endear him to me! Come Vince, rise,
Next time I see her, I will give her this:
Which when she sees, she'll think it wondrous strange
Love should go by descent, and make the son
Follow the father in his amorous steps.
She needs must think it strange, that never yet saw
I durst speak to her, or had scarce her sight.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well Vince, I swear thou shalt both see and kiss her.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: Swears my dear friend? by what?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Even by our friendship.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O sacred oath! which, how long will you keep?

lg.l: While there be bees in Hybla, or white swan's
In bright Meander; while the banks of Po
Shall bear brave lilies; or Italian dames
Be called the bone robes of the world.
'Tis elegantly said: and when I fail,
Let there be found in Hybla hives no bees;
Let no swans swim in bright Meander stream ▪
Nor lilies spring upon the banks of Po,
Nor let one fat Italian dame be found,
But lean and brawn-fallen; ay, and scarcely so●nd.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: It is enough, but let's embrace with all.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So, now farewell sweet Vince.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Farewell my worthy friend, I think I have him.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I had forgotten the parting phrase he taught me, I commend me t'ee sir.

sp.speaker: Vin.

lg.l: At your wish● service sir:
Oh fine friend, he had forgotten the phrase:
How serious apish souls are in vain form:
Well, he is mine, and he being trusted most
With my dear Jove, may often work our meeting,
And being thus engaged, dare not reveal.

sp.stage: Enter P●gio in haste, Strozza following.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Horse, horse, horse, my lord, horse, your father is going a hunting.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: My lord horse? you ass you d'e● call my lord horse?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Nay, he speaks huddles still, let's sl● h● tongue.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Nay good uncle now, 'sblood, what cap●, merchants you be; so the Duke took me up even now: my lord uncle here, and my old lord Lasso, by heaven you're all too witty for me, I am the veriest fool on you all, ●e be sworn.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Therein thou art worth us all, for thou knowest thyself.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But your w●edom was in a pretty t●g last night; was it not I pray?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p:
O, for taking my drink a little? faith my lord, for that you shall have the best sport p●ntly with Mad●cor●,
that ever was; I have made her so drunk, that she does nothing but kiss my lord Medice.
See she comes riding the Duke, she's passing well mounted ▪ believe it.
sp.stage: Enter Alphonso, Corteza, Cynanche Bassiolo first, two women attendants, and huntsmen, Lasso.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Good wench forbear.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: My lord, you must put forth yourself among ladies, I warrant you have much in you, if you would show it; see, a cheek a twenty; the body of a George, a good leg still; still a good calf ▪ and not slabby, nor hanging I warrant you; a brawn of a thumb here, and 'twere a p●d p●; niece Meg●ou shalt have the sweetest bedfellow on him, that ever called lady husband; try him you shamefaced babble you, try him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good madam be ruled.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: What a nice thing it is, my lord, you must set forth this g●re ▪ and k●e her; i'faith you must; get you together and be naught awhile, get you together.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Now what a merry harmless dame it is!

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: My lord Medice, you are a right noble man, and will do a woman right in a wrong matter and need be; prav do you give the Duke ensample upon me; you come a-wooing to me now; I accept it.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: What ●ane you sister?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: Pray my lord away; consider me as I am, a woman.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Lord, how I have wh●d her?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: You come a-wooing to me now; ●ay ●ee Duke mark my lord Medi●; and do you mar●e me virgin▪; stand you aside, my lord ▪ all, and you; g● pl●; now ●y L●●edice, ●ut case I be stage a 〈◊〉 yet y● like 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 to it. Come ●e me my l●d, be not ashamed.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Not I Mad●, I come no● a ●ng to ●ou.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Fie sister, you're too 〈◊〉; pray will you go to your chamber

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: D'ye think I am drunk?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: I think so truly.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: But are you sure I am drunk?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Else I would not think so.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: But, I would be glad to be sure on't.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: I assure you then.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: Why then say nothing; and I'll begone God bye lord, Duke
I'll come again anon.

lg.l: I hope your grace will pardon her my liege,
For 'tis most strange; she's as discreet a dame
As any in these countries, and as sober,
But for this only humour of the cup
'Tis good my lord sometimes:
Come, to our hunting; now 'tis time I think.
The very best time of the day, my lord.
Then my lord, I will take my leave till night,
Reserving thanks for all my entertainment,
Till I return; in mean time, lovely dame,
Remember the high state you last presented,Vin. and st. have all this while talked together a pretty way.
And think it was not a mere festival show,
But an essential type of that you are
In full consent of all my faculties
And hark you good my lord.
See now, they whisper
Some private order, (I dare lay my life)
For a forced marriage twixt my love and father ▪
I therefore must make sure: and noble friends,
I'll leave you all, when I have brought you forth,
And seen you in the chase; meanwhile observe
In all the time this solemn hunting lasts,
My father and his minion Medice,
And note, if you can gather any sign,
That they have missed me, and suspect my being,
If which fall out, send home my page before.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I will not fail my lord.
sp.stage: Medice whispers with i ▪ Huntsman all this while.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Now take thy time.

sp.speaker: Huntsman
sp.p: I warrant you my lord, he shall not scape me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Now my dear mistress, till our sports intended end with my absence, I will take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Bassiolo, attend you on my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I will my lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Now will the sport begin; I think my love will handle him, as well as I have done.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Madam, I take my leave, and humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Welcome good madam; maids wait on my lady.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So mistress, this is fit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fit sir, why so?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why so? I have most fortunate news for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For me sir? I beseech you what are they?

lg.l: Merit and fortune, for you both agree;
Merit what you have, and have what you merit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord with what rhetoric you prepare your news ▪

lg.l: I need not; for the plain contents they bear
Uttered in any words, deserve their welcome,
And yet I hope the words will serve the turn.

sp.speaker: Ma●
sp.p: What, in a letter?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whence is it?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: From one that will not shame it with his name ▪ and that is lord Vincentio.

lg.l: King of heaven!
Is the man mad?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Mad madam, why?

lg.l: O heaven, I muse a man of your importance,
Will offer to bring me a letter thus?
Why, why good mistress, are you hurt in that?
Your answer may be what you will yourself.
Ay, but you should not do it: gods my life,
You shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, you must answer it.

lg.l: I answer it! are you the man I trusted?
And will betray me to a stranger thus?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: That's nothing, dame, all friends were strangers first.

lg.l: Now was there ever woman overseen so,
In a wise man's discretion?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Your brain is shallow, come, receive this letter ▪

lg.l: How dare you say so? when you know so well
How much I am engaged to the Duke?
The Duke? A proper match: a grave old gentman:
Has beard at will; and would, in my conceit,
Make a most excellent pattern, for a potter
To have his picture stamped on a jug.
To keep ale-knights in memory of sobriety.
Here gentle madam, take it.
Take it sir?
Am I common taker of love letters?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Common? why when received you one before?

lg.l: Come, 'tis no matter; I had thought your care
Of my bestowing, would not tempt me thus
To one I know not; but it is because
You know I dote so much on your direction.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: On my direction?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No sir, not on yours.

lg.l: Well mistress, if you will take my advice
At any time, then take this letter now.
'Tis strange, I wonder the coy gentleman,
That seeing me so oft, would never speak,
Is on the sudden so far wrapped to write.
It showed his judgement, that he would not speak
Knowing with what a strict and jealous eye
He should be noted; hold, if you love yourself;
Now will you take this letter? pray be ruled.
Come, you have such another plaguy tongue,
And yet i'fath I will not.
Lord of heaven,
What, did it burn your hands? hold, hold, I pray,
And let the words within it fire your heart.
I wonder how the devil, he found you our
To be his spokesman, — oh the Duke would thank you,
If he knew how you urged me for his son.
The Duke? I have fretted her,
Even to the liver, and had much ado
To make her take it, but I knew was sure;
For he that cannot turn and wind a woman
Like silk about his finger, is no man,
I'll make her answer't too.
O here's good stuff.
Hold, pray take it for your pains to bring it.
Lady you err in my reward a little,
Which must be a kind answer to this letter.
Nay then i'faith, 'twere best you brought a priest;
And than your client; and then keep the door.
God me I never knew so rude a man.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well, you shall answer; I'll fetch pen and paper.

lg.l: Poor usher, how wert thou wrought to this brake?
Men work on one another for we women,
Nay each man on himself; and all in one
Say; no man is content that lies alone.
Here comes our gulled squire.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Here mistress, write.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What should I write?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: An answer to this letter.

lg.l: Why sir, I see no cause of answer in it,
But if you needs will show how much you rule me,
Sit down; and answer it, as you please yourself,
Here is your paper, lay it fair afore you.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Lady, content, I'll be your secretary.

lg.l: I fit him in this task; he walks his pen
The shaft of Cupid, in an amorous letter.
Is here no great worth of your answer say you?
Believe it, 'tis exceedingly well writ.
So much the more unfit for me to answer,
And therefore let your style and it contend.
Well, you shall see I will not be far short,
Although (Indeed) I cannot write so well
When one is by, as when I am alone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O, a good scribe must write, though twenty talk, and he talk to them too.

sp.speaker: B●ss.
sp.p: Well, you shall see.

lg.l: A proper piece of scribeship there's no doubt;
Some words, pick out of proclamations,
Or great men's speeches; or well selling pamphlets:
See how he rubs his temples 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
His muse lies in the back - 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
which thick and gross, is hard to be brought forward,
What? is it loath to come?
No, not a whi●:
Pray hold your peace a little.
He sweats, with bringing on his heavy style,
I'll ply him still, till he sweat all his wit out,
What man, not yet?
Swoons, you'll not extort it from a man,
How do you like the word endear?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O fie upon't.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, than I see your judgement: what say you to condole?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O brave● I should make a sweet answer, if I should use no words but of your admittance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well sir, write what you please.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Is model a good word with you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Put them together I pray.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So I will I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: See, see, see, now it comes pouring down.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I hope you'll take no exceptions to believe it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Out upon't, that phrase is so run out of breath in trifles, that we shall have no belief at all in earnest shortly. Believe it 'tis a pretty feather; believe it a dainty rush; believe it an excellent coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So, so, so, your exceptions sort very collaterally.

sp.speaker: M●r.
sp.p: Collaterally? there's a fine word now; wrest in that if you can by any means.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I thought she would like the very worst of them all, how think you? do not I write, and hear, and talk too now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By my soul, if you can tell what you write now, you write very readily.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: That you shall see straight.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But do you not write that you speak now?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O yes, do you not see how I write it? I can not write when anybody is by me, I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: God's my life, stay man; you'll make it too long.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, if I can not tell what belongs to the length of a lady's device i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But I will not have it so long.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: If I cannot fit you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O me; how it comes upon him? pray thee be short.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well, now I have done, and now I will read it; your lordship's motive accommodating my thoughts, with the very model of my hearts mature consideration: it shall not be out of my element to negotiate with you in this amorous duello; wherein I will condole with you, that our project cannot be foe collaterally made, as our endeared hearts may very well seem to insinuate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No more: no more; fie upon this.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Fie upon this? he's accursed that has to do with these unsound women, of judgement: if this be not good i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But 'tis so good, 'twill not be thought to come from a woman's brain.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: That's another matter

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, I will write myself.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: A god's name lady: and yet I will not lose this I warrant you; I know for what lady this will serve as fit; now we shall have a sweet piece of indictment.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How spell you foolish?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: F, oo, l, i. sh ▪ she will presume t'endite that cannot spell:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How spell you usher?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: 'Sblood, you put not in those words together, do you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, not together.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: What is betwixt I pray?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ass the.

lg.l: Ass the? betwixt foolish, and usher,
God's my life, foolish ass the usher?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay then you are so jealous of your wit: now read all I have written I pray.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: I am not so foolish as the usher would make me: oh so foolish as the usher would make me? Wherein would I make you foolish?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why sir, in willing me to believe he loved me so well, being so mere a stranger.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O, is't so? you may say so indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Cry mercy sir, and I will write so too, and yet my hand is so vile, pray thee sit thee down and write as I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: With all my heart lady, what shall I write now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You shall write this sir, I am not so foolish to think you love me, being so mere a stranger.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So mere a stranger!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And yet I know, love works strangely.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Love works strangely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And therefore take heed, by whom you speak for love.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Speak for love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For he may speak for himself.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: May speak for himself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not that I desire it,

sp.speaker: B●ss
sp.p: Desire it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But if he do ▪ you may speed, I confess.

sp.speaker: Basse.
sp.p: Speed I confess.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But let that pass, I do not love to discourage anybody .

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Discourage ●y body.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Do you or he ●icke out what you can; and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: And so fare well. Is this all?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay, and he may thank your Siren's tongue that it is so much.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: A proper letter if you mark it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well sir, though it be not so proper as the writer; yet 'tis as proper as the ●diter; every woman cannot be a gentleman usher; they that cannot go before, must come behind.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well lady, this I will carry instantly, I commend me tee lady.

lg.l: Pitiful usher, what a pretty sleight,
Goes to the working up of every thing?
What sweet variety serves a woman's wit?
We make men sue to us for that we wish.
Poor men; hold out a while; and do not sue,
And spite of custom we will see t●●ou.

div.head: Actus qvarti,
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Pogi● running in and knockin at 〈◊〉 door.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: O Go●, how weary I am? Aunt, madam. Cynanche, aunt?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: O God, aunt: oh God aunt: oh God.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: What bad news brings this man? where is my lord?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: O aunt, my uncle, he's shot.

lg.l: Shot, ay me!
How is he shot?
Why with a forked shaft
As he was hunting, full in his left side.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O me accursed, where is he? bring me, where?

sp.speaker: Pog.

lg.l: Coming with doctor Benivemus,
I'll leave you, and go tell my lord Vincentio.

sp.stage: Enter Beniuemus with others, bringing in Strozza with an arrow in his side.

lg.l: See the sad sight, I dare not yield to grief,
But force feigned patience to recomfort him:
My lord, what chance is this? how fares your lordship?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Wounded, and faint with anguish, let me rest.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: A chair.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O doctor, is't a deadly hurt?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I hope not madam, though not free from danger ▪

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Why pluck you not the arrow from his side?

lg.l: We cannot lady, the forked head so fast
Sticks in the bottom of his solid rib.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: No mean then doctor rests there to educe it?

lg.l: This only, my good lord, to give your wound
A greater orifice, and in sunder break
The pierced rib; which being so near the midriff,
And opening to the region of the heart,
Will be exceeding dangerous to your life.
I will not see my bosom mangled so,
Nor sternly be anatomized alive,
I'll rather perish with it sticking still.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O no; sweet doctor think upon some help.

lg.l: I told you all that can be thought in art,
Which since your lordship will not yield to use,
Our last hope rests in nature's secret aid,
Whose power at length may happily expel it.
Must we attend at death's abhorred door,
the torturing delays of slavish nature?
My life is in mine own powers to dissolve:
And why not then the pains that plague my life?
Rise furies, and this fury of my bane,
Assail and conquer; what men madness call
(That hath no eye to sense, but frees the foul,
Exempt of hope, and fear with instant fate)
Is manliest reason; manliest reason then,
Resolve and rid me of this brutish life,
Hasten the cowardly protracted cure
Of all diseases: King of physicians, death,
I'll dig thee from this mine of misery.
O hold my lord, this is no christian part,
Nor yet scarce manly, when your mankind foe,
Imperious death shall make your groans his trumpets
To summon resignation of life's fort,
To fly without resistance; you must force
A countermine of fortitude, more deep
Than this poor mine of pains, to blow him up,
And spite of him live victor, though subdued:
Patience in torment, is a valour more
Than ever crowned th' alcmenean conqueror.

sp.speaker: ●ro
sp.p: Rage is the vent of torment, let me rise.

lg.l: Men do but cry, that rage in miseries,
And scarcely beaten children, become cries:
Pains are like women's clamours, which the less
They find men's patience stirred, the more they cease.
Of this 'tis said, afflictions bring to God,
Because they make us like him, drinking up
Joys that deform us with the lusts of sense,
And turn our general being into soul,
Whose actions simply formed and applied,
Draw all our bodies frailties from respect.
Away with this unmedicinable balm
Of worded breath; for bear friends, let me rest,
I swear I will be bands unto myself.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: That will become your lordship best indeed.

lg.l: I'll break away, and leap into the sea.
Or from some turret cast me headlong down,
To shiver this frail carcase into dust.
O my dear lord, what unlike words are these ▪
To the late fruits of your religious noblesse?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Leave me fond woman.

lg.l: I'll be hewn from hence
Before I leave you; help me gentle doctor ▪

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Have patience good my lord.

lg.l: Then lead me in,
Cut off the timber of this cursed shaft,
And let the forked pile canker to my heart.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Dear lord, resolve on humble sufferance.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I will not hear thee, woman, be content.

sp.speaker: Cyn.

lg.l: O never shall my counsels cease to knock
At thy impatient ears, till they fly in
And salve with christian patience, pagan sin.

sp.stage: Enter Vincentio with a letter in his hand, Bassiolo.

lg.l: This is her letter sir, you now shall see
How silly a thing 'tis in respect of mine,
And what a simple woman she has proved,
To refuse mine for hers; I pray look here.
Soft sir, I know not, I being her sworn servant,
If I may put up these disgraceful words,
Given of my mistress, without touch of honour.
Disgraceful words; I protest I speak not
To disgrace her, but to grace myself.
Nay then sir, if it be to grace yourself,
I am content; but otherwise you know,
I was to take exceptions to a King.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Nay, you're ith' right for that; but read I pray ▪ if there be not more choice words in that letter, than in any three of G●evaras' golden epistles, I am a very ass. How think you vince?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: By heaven no less sir, it is the best thing;
Gods what a beast am I.

lg.l: Is is no matter,
I can set it together again.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Pardon me sir, I protest I was ravished: but was it possible she should prefer hers before this?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O sir, she cried fie upon this.
Well, I must say nothing, love is blind you know, and can find no fault in his beloved.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, that's most certain.
Gi't me: I'll have this letter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: No good Vince, 'tis not worth it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I'll have't i'faith, here's enough in it to serve for my letters as long as I live; I'll keep it to breed on as 'twere:
But I much wonder you could make her write.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Indeed there were some words belonged to that.

lg.l: How strong an influence works in well placed words,
And yet there must be a prepared love,
To give those words so mighty a command,
Or 'twere impossible they should move so much:
And will you tell me true?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: In any thing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Does not this lady love you?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Love me? why yes; I think she does not hate me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Nay but i'faith, does she not love you dear?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: No I protest.
Nor have you never kissed her?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Kissed her, that's nothing.

lg.l: But you know my meaning:
Have you not been, as one would say, afore me?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Not I, I swear.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O, you're too true to tell.

lg.l: Nay be my troth, she has, I must confess,
Used me with good respect, and nobly still,
But for such matters.
Very little more,
Would make him take her maidenhead upon him:
Well friend, I rest yet in a little doubt,
This was not hers.
Was by that light that shines,
And I'll go fetch her to you to confirm it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O passing friend.

lg.l: But when she comes, in any case be bold,
And come upon her with some pleasing thing,
To show you're pleased: however she behaves her,
as for example; if she turn her back,
Use you that action you would do before,
And court her thus; lady, your back part is as fair to me, as is your fore part.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: 'Twill be most pleasing.

lg.l: Ay, for if you love
One part above another, 'tis a sign
You like not all alike, and the worst part
About your mistress, you must think as fair,
As sweet, and dainty, as the very best,
So much, for so much, and considering too,
Each several limb and member in his kind.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: As a man should.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: True, will you think of this?

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: I hope I shall.

lg.l: But if she chance to laugh,
You must not lose your countenance, but devise
Some speech to show you pleased, even being laughed at.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ay, but what speech?

lg.l: God's precious man! do something of yourself?
But I'll devise a speech.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Inspire him folly.

lg.l: Or 'tis no matter, be but bold enough,
And laugh when she laughs, and it is enough:
I'll fetch her to you.
Now was there ever such a demi-lance,
To bear a man so clear through thick and thin?
Or hark you sir, if she should steal a laughter
Under her fan, thus you may say, sweet lady,
If you will laugh and lie down, I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And so I were by heaven; how know you that?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: 'Slid man ▪ I'll hit your very thoughts in these things.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Fetch her sweet friend, I'll hit your words I warrant,

lg.l: Be bold than Vince, and press her to it hard,
A shamefaced man, is of all women barred.
How easily worthless men take worth upon them,
And being over credulous of their own worths,
Do underprize as much the worth of others.
The fool is rich, and absurd riches thinks
All merit is rung out, where his purse chinks.
My lord, with much entreaty here's my lady.
Nay madam, look not back: why Vince I say?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Vince? O monstrous jest!

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: To her for shame.

lg.l: Lady, your back part is as sweet to me
As all your forc part.
He missed a little: he said her back part was sweet, when
He should have said fair; but see, she laughs most fitly,
To bring in the tother: Vince, to her again, she laughs.
Laugh you fair dame?
If you will laugh and lie down, I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What villainous stuff is here?

lg.l: Sweet mistress, of mere grace embolden now
The kind young prince here, it is only love
Upon my protestation, that thus daunts
His most heroic spirit: so a while
I'll leave you close together; Vince, I say —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O horrible hearing, does he call you Vince?

lg.l: O ay, what else? and I made him embrace me,
Knitting a most familiar league of friendship.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But wherefore did you court me so absurdly?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: God's me, he taught me, I spoke out of him.

lg.l: O fie upon't, could you for pity make him
Such a poor creature? 'twas abuse enough
To make him take on him such saucy friendship;
And yet his place is great; for he's not only
My father's usher, but the worlds beside,
Because he goes before it all in folly.
Well, in these homely wiles, must our loves mask,
Since power denies him his apparent right,
But is there no mean to dissolve that power,
And to prevent all further wrong to us,
Which it may work, by forcing marriage rites,
Betwixt me and the Duke?
No mean but one,
and that is closely to be married first,
Which I perceive not how we can perform:
For at my father's coming back from hunting,
I fear your father and himself resolve,
To bar my interest with his present nuptials.
That shall they never do; may not we now
Our contract make, and marry before heaven?
Are not the laws of God and nature, more
Than formal laws of men? are outward rites,
More virtuous than the very substance is
Of holy nuptials solemnized within?
Or shall laws made to curb the common world,
That would not be contained in form without them,
Hurt them that be a law unto themselves?
My princely love, 'tis not a priest shall let us:
But since th'eternal acts of our pure souls,
Knit us with God, the soul of all the world,
He shall be priest to us; and with such rites
As we can here devise, we will express,
And strongly ratify our hearts true vows,
Which no external violence shall dissolve.
This is our only mean t'enjoy each other:
And, my dear life, I will devise a form
To execute the substance of our minds,
In honoured nuptialls. First then hide your face
With this your spotless white and virgin veil:
Now this my scarf I'll knit about your arm,
As you shall knit this other end on mine,
And as I knit it, here I vow by heaven,
By the most sweet imaginary joys,
Of untried nuptials; by love's ushering fire,
Fore-melting beauty, and love's flame itself.
As this is soft and pliant to your arm
In a circumferent flexure, so will I
Be tender of your welfare and your will,
As of mine own, as of my life and soul,
In all things, and for ever; only you
Shall have this care in fullness, only you
